stem: A 54-year-old client with a confirmed large pulmonary embolism (PE) is now hypotensive and unresponsive. Based on the documentation in the Critical Care Infusion & Bleeding Precautions tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Progression to massive (obstructive) PE.
Background: DVT-to-PE transition. Initial treatment was Heparin.
Assessment: BP has dropped to 72/40. Client is cyanotic around the mouth.
Recommendation: Rescue thrombolytic therapy.

tabs.title: Infusion & Procedure Prep
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent StatusInterpretation
OrderAlteplase (t-PA) 100mg IVThrombolytic / Clot Buster
ConsentEmergency impliedLife-threatening
AccessTwo 18G IVsAdequate
Bleeding RiskHistory of major GI bleed 2 yrs agoRelative contraindication

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 72/40, HR 142, RR 36, SpO2 78% on 15L NRM.

conditionOptions.text: Massive Pulmonary Embolism with Obstructive Shock

actionOptions.text: Administer Alteplase (t-PA) IV infusion as prescribed
Avoid all invasive procedures (Injections/Catheters) once infusion starts
Increase the IV Heparin rate to match the t-PA speed
Elevate the legs above the level of the heart to prevent DVT

parameterOptions.text: Level of consciousness and pupil response (Assess for ICH)
Blood pressure and MAP (Assess for resolution of shock)
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Peak flow meter readings every 8 hours

rationale.correct: This client is in Obstructive Shock (Massive PE) (c2) as evidenced by hypotension (BP 72/40) and severe hypoxia. Conventional anticoagulation (Heparin) is not enough; the clot must be dissolved. Alteplase (t-PA) (a1) is the drug of choice for hemodynamically unstable PE. Once t-PA is started, the client is at extreme risk for bleeding; hence, no new invasive procedures (a2) should be performed. The nurse must monitor for intracranial hemorrhage (p1) (the most feared side effect) and the return of a stable BP (p2).
clinicalPearls: Thrombolytics ('Clot Busters') dissolve the fibrin mesh. Anticoagulants (Heparin) just prevent new mesh from forming.
Massive PE = SBP < 90 or a drop of > 40 mmHg from baseline for > 15 mins.
The pulse oximetry is often inaccurate in shock because of low peripheral perfusion; ABGs are preferred.

questionTrap.trap: Drawing blood gases or starting a Foley AFTER the t-PA has started.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Get all invasive 'pokes' done BEFORE giving the thrombolytic. Once it's in the system, any hole will bleed uncontrollably.

mnemonic.title: t-PA Trip
mnemonic.expansion: T-Target the clot. P-Punctures avoided (Bleeding). A-Assess Neuro (Stroke risk).
